â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

http://www.artspace.com/magazine/interviews_features/body-of-art/jeffrey-deitch-miami-interview-53310

â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

Ever since Jeffrey Deitch returned early last year from his controversial stint as director of MOCA in Los Angeles, the art world has been wondering about his next chapter. There have been signs of an attempt to re-create the vital infusion of art, design, fashion, nightlife, and street culture that was Deitch Projects in its earlier incarnation, with a tribute show to the 1980s nightclub Area (held at his protÃ©gÃ© Kathy Graysonâ€˜s Hole Gallery) and an exhibition of street art in Coney Island, but also reports of a lucrative consulting practice and a renewed focus on his time-honored trade in the secondary market.

As 2015 draws to a close, however, a clearer strategy is starting to gelâ€”one that makes use of both Deitchâ€™s private-dealing acumen and his status as an impresario of pop-up shows and special events. For Art Basel Miami Beach, for instance, he has teamed up with none other than Larry Gagosian on an exhibition, â€œUnrealism,â€ that will fill the atrium of the Moore Building with figurative painting and sculpture from the 1980s (Julian Schnabel, Francesco Clemente) to the right-this-minute (Jamian Juliano-Villani, Sascha Braunig).

This clearly sales-oriented, object-centric exhibition may sound a bit staid for a Deitch event in Miamiâ€”this is, after all, the man who invited Miley Cyrus to peform at the Raleigh last year. But it also capitalizes on a new wave of figuration by younger artists who have tired of neo-formalist abstraction (a topic we have been covering in our conversation series surrounding Phaidonâ€˜s new book Body of Art). And in characteristic Deitch fashion, it will incorporate a festive performance: an exuberant, costumed parade through the Design District by the voguing video artist Rashaad Newsome.

Meanwhile, Deitch is also working on â€œOverpop,â€ a touring international group show scheduled to debut in Shanghai in 2017 that explores Pop influences in Post-Internet art. And closer to homeâ€”much closer, in factâ€”he has big plans for the year ahead. Deitch sat down with Artspaceâ€™s Karen Rosenberg at his Grand Street space to talk about the resurgence of figurative art, the evolving downtown art scene, and whatâ€™s next for him and his gallery.

What inspired you to do a show of figurative painting and sculpture? At first glance, this exhibition looks a lot more conservative than your usual programming.

This has been an interest of mine going way, way back. In 1984, I organized a big exhibition at P.S.1 called â€œThe New Portraitâ€ that took up the entire second floor. It was a portrait salon, and Andy Warhol helped me organize it. We had one room that was Pictures Generation artists like Robert Longo, a Jean-Michel Basquiat and Keith Haring room, photography rooms. In the center, we had a fantastic display of Warholâ€™s portraits of artists. So Iâ€™ve been interested in this from the beginning. Figurative art is like the novelâ€”itâ€™s reinvented by every generation, and gives us insights into how artists are perceiving life today.

I had planned, at MOCA, a show on new figurative painting. If youâ€™ve gone to the Museum of Modern Art over the past 15 years, or most other American museums, youâ€™ve hardly seen any figurative painting on view. Thatâ€™s really what most artists do, and what the general public generally expects out of painting. They relate to it. Iâ€™m as steeped in conceptual art as anyoneâ€”I worked at the John Weber gallery in the â€˜70sâ€”but itâ€™s something I was thinking about when I went to a museum. Thereâ€™s hardly been an ambitious exhibition of new figurative painting in any American museum in a long time.

Can you tell me more about that unrealized MOCA show? How close is â€œUnrealismâ€ to your original vision?

At MOCA I was planning on doing it with Alison Gingeras as a guest curator. I loved the show that she did at the Pompidou, more than 10 years ago, called â€œDear Painterâ€â€”the title is taken from Martin Kippenberger. Alison is quite interested in a kind of counter-history of figurative painting, and she notoriously included Bernard Buffet in that show. The theme that Alison was interested in was â€œwrongnessâ€ in figuration. It started with Giorgio de Chirico, Francis Picabia, other figures like that, and went into the present.

We never were able to do that show. But I still had this desire to do a really strong show on new figurative painting, and I just adapted it to this commercial situationâ€”a show thatâ€™s supported by making sales, which we do in this sector. My original title for the MOCA show was â€œUnrealism,â€ because I love titles like this that have some ambiguity. Alison preferred â€œWrong Figures,â€ so that was our title there, but here I went back to â€œUnrealism, and itâ€™s a much more compact history, because for a one-week show we canâ€™t be borrowing de Chiricos.

Were you also thinking about the ideas from your 1993 touring show in Europe, â€œPost Humanâ€? That exhibition, which focused on the reshaping of the body through futuristic technologies, seems so prescient now in our age of Post-Internet art.

â€œPost Humanâ€ is the inspiration for another show Iâ€™m working on, â€œOverpop.â€ Itâ€™s great that itâ€™s had this second life. Iâ€™ve done so much, and most of it unfortunately just disappears into the ether. You hope that cumulatively, it made some statement.

There are number of artists, like Maurizio Cattelan, Vanessa Beecroft, and the Chapman Brothers, whose work comes right out of â€œPost Human,â€ and they actually acknowledge that. And, subsequently, Urs Fischer was very influenced by the show, even though his work is not really in this vein.

Whatâ€™s very gratifying for me is that when I first met Josh Kline, I said, â€œBy any chance did you hear of a show I did called â€˜Post Humanâ€™? And he said, â€œOf course!â€ He even has the book. Itâ€™s a real reference for Josh and a number of other artists, who somehow got hold of the book at a used bookstore.

I want to hear more about â€œOverpop.â€ But first, who are the artists in â€œUnrealismâ€?

This show was also inspired by a group of very exciting young figurative painters Iâ€™ve discovered over the past few years. In New York thereâ€™s Ella Kruglyanskya, Jamian Juliano-Villani, and Emily Mae Smith, and, in L.A., Tala Madani. In Germany, thereâ€™s Jana Euler. In Maine, Sascha Braunig. Thereâ€™s Jonathan Gardner, whoâ€™s just moved to New York from Chicago. I think some of these artists are exceptional talents, and a perfect example of reinventing figuration to connect with contemporary experience.

These artists are very knowledgeable about historical precedents. Theyâ€™ve studied traditional technique, but itâ€™s very, very fresh. Ella, Tala, and Sascha all studied for their MFAs at Yale, and they intersected with Kurt Kauper, whoâ€™s an artist I used to show and a great teacher. Others like Jamian, who went to Rutgers and is much more self-taught, are looking at unexpected sourcesâ€”monster magazines, old Playboys, things like that.

Iâ€™m very excited about these artists, and if I could get enough material I would do a show just with them. But theyâ€™re so in-demand, and just to get what we got was a real achievement. I thought it would be interesting to put them in a context with several other generations of contemporary figurative painters, who are continuing to do vital work and are changing with the times.

Who are some of those other painters?

We start with the â€˜80s generationâ€”Francesco Clemente, George Condo, Julian Schnabel, Richard Prince. Then, from the â€˜90s generation, John Currin, Rachel Feinstein, Elizabeth Peyton, Karen Kilimnik, Cecily Brown, and others. We have others who go beyond the New York group, like Henry Taylor from Los Angeles. space lends itself to sculpture as wellâ€”the entrance will be an Urs Fischer candle portrait of Michael Chow, which will burn during the show, and weâ€™ll have two great Duane Hansons.

What about the many artists who combine figuration and abstraction? How strict were your parameters?

Itâ€™s such an open, big topic, but we wanted to keep it as coherent as we could. Iâ€™m not one to make restrictions on media, but rather than having all kinds of mediaâ€”photography, video, immersive installationsâ€”I decided to keep it a tighter show. Itâ€™s painting, and a small amount of sculpture, and most of the painting is figurative. Thereâ€™s one painting that is notâ€”itâ€™s a Dan Colen interior. Itâ€™s always good to have one thing that throws it off.

Will there be performance?

Yes. The opening will have a procession and performance by Rashaad Newsome. I got the idea from a video of a procession he did in New Orleans, called King of Arms, which I thought was incredible. Heâ€™s very involved in the new vogueing scene, and weâ€™re bringing voguers down from New York. Weâ€™re going to have a marching band from Miami. Weâ€™re doing a procession that will start at the de la Cruz space and go through the Design District. Itâ€™s a big challenge, because there are going to be a lot of cars coming in and we have to figure out the whole traffic pattern. But itâ€™s going to be worth it, because itâ€™s going to be very exuberant. Iâ€™d like to do more, but itâ€™s a short show. If I were to do the show in New York, there would be more of a performance component.

Do you see performance in general, particularly some of the performances youâ€™ve done at your galleryâ€”for example, Colen and Dash Snowâ€™s â€œThe Nestâ€â€”as part of the figurative tradition?

Oh, absolutely. Part of the revival of figuration, in the early â€˜80s, came out of performance. When I was the American editor of Flash Art years ago, we did a whole issue of performance into painting. It was a big topic thenâ€”the mainstream galleries were conceptual/Minimal, and there were a few galleries showing photorealism, but you werenâ€™t even allowed to talk about going there. There wasnâ€™t much of a place to go for the younger generation.

My whole group would go to performances at the Kitchen and CBGB when that started up, and a lot of the people who became painters at that stage were in bands, doing performance art, making vanguard film. Somehow it all converged into a more iconic image, into painting. Performance is so crucial to that shiftâ€”the dialogue between Cindy Sherman and other artists in her circle like Longo or David Salle, who went to CalArts with all the dance and performance art and turned it into paintings. Thatâ€™s very, very important. Today, for many painters the references are film, TV, the videos that people send around on social networkingâ€”thatâ€™s very much part of the vocabulary.

In a recent interview with the New York Times you spoke about the appeal of humanism at this moment, when artists have been preoccupied with â€œinside-art issues.â€ Can you elaborate on that?

Even though I have a whole history of exploring figuration, Iâ€™m equally interested in abstraction. The most important show that I did at MOCA, for me, was â€œThe Painting Factory,â€ a survey of new abstraction. So itâ€™s not that I think this is betterâ€”what happens is that a chapter gets completed; it plays out. Thereâ€™s a lot of achievement, when you look at Julie Mehretu, Mark Bradford, Wade Guyton, Tauba Auerbach. But now you see that the field is diluted by second-tier abstractionistsâ€”I donâ€™t want to mention any namesâ€”who are using printing techniques and kind of a conceptual story, and itâ€™s just not as good.

It reminds me of Post-Minimalism when I came into the scene in the â€˜70s, after Robert Ryman and Robert Mangold and Brice Mardenâ€”there were dozens of artists doing Minimalist-type painting, and most of itâ€™s completely disappeared. I just see that something similar is happening with the abstract dialogueâ€”itâ€™s played-out. Younger artists recognize that, and ambitious people are going in a fresh direction. There are cycles. After the â€˜80s, people had had it with fabricated, market-ready sculpture, and then there was more of the etherealâ€”Felix Gonzalez-Torres installations, things like that.

You can see the next cycle starting in the current â€œGreater New Yorkâ€ survey at MoMA P.S.1 and in last springâ€™s New Museum Triennial.

Thatâ€™s right. The interest in the figurative never goes away, and I love that it reappears in a fresh way that reflects contemporary experience.

How exactly are these younger artists youâ€™re championing in â€œUnrealismâ€ making the figure new again?

Theyâ€™re all different. Ella is probably the most traditionalâ€”sheâ€™s looking very carefully at Picasso and Matisse, and even that is somehow fresh because that has not been so much of a reference for vanguard painters. But thereâ€™s also something that connects with fashion illustration and the expanding art platform and the confusion of whatâ€™s art and whatâ€™s fashion and whatâ€™s popular culture. Sheâ€™s involved with that. I see references to Picasso, but I also see references to fashion illustrators like Antonio Lopez.

Jamian is interested in Surrealismâ€”in her work you see Yves Tanguy, and also Mexican women Surrealists like Remedios Varo. Sheâ€™s looking at that more Feminist art history. But sheâ€™s also into weird non-art stuff, like H. R. Giger science fiction illustration. Sheâ€™s brilliant at finding all these obscure sources, including some artists who were neglected but are coming back, like Christina Rambergâ€”she has every book on Ramberg. She addresses something very contemporary, which is increasing confusion between fine art and popular culture. Itâ€™s all colliding. Her studio is this crazy mezzanine in somebodyâ€™s silkscreen shop. If the building department ever came, people would get arrested! You know how artists have to work in New York, even successful ones.

How you think the conditions for making and showing art in New York have changed in recent years? Did anything surprise you when you came back from California?

In five years, the studios have gotten more and more miserable. In the â€˜70s, people in my circle had entire floors in SoHo and Tribeca that were really cheapâ€”young people that had just arrived. Then the ones who still had their leases divided them up into warrens. Then people had really nice places in Williamsburg, but that fell apart for artists pretty quickly. Then it was nice places in Bushwick. And now itâ€™s like youâ€™re in some institution, where some real-estate sharpie has rented a floor and divided it into 30 cubicles. Itâ€™s like youâ€™re in some state hospital. Everyone has a cubicle, but they keep the doors all shut.

Itâ€™s much tougher to be an artist here, and I really admire people for being here and pushing it. Itâ€™s not as pleasant as it was for my generation. People say, â€œLetâ€™s all move to L.A,â€ but itâ€™s still so dynamic in New York. With this group of artists Iâ€™m looking at with the new figurative painting, thereâ€™s more talent in New York than L.A. Itâ€™s the dialogue, the social networking of people seeing each other in person and talking and hanging out. And the standards that are hereâ€”you canâ€™t have a half-baked exhibition and keep your position. Itâ€™s changing in L.A., but until recently people had half-baked exhibitions, and it was sort of still ok.

Did working within that institutional structure of MOCA change anything about the way you organize exhibitions?

Itâ€™s so ironic, but when I did the shows here I never had to think of commercial considerations. We always had something going that would help to pay for it. My business philosophy was, if you do something inspiring, someone is going to want to buy something. And it worked.

In a museum, thereâ€™s more compromise. There are certain things you canâ€™t include because a sponsor might find it offensive. Then, say thereâ€™s an important patron of the museum who collects an artistâ€¦. All the museums say, â€œOh, we donâ€™t do this,â€ but if your big trustee is a big collector of this artist, well, you basically have to put that artist in. You donâ€™t really advertise it, but thatâ€™s the reality.

But the thing that really astonished me is that if youâ€™re a museum director and, increasingly, a museum curator, the majority of your time is spent fundraising. I was quoted someplace saying that when I had Deitch Projects it was 90 percent art and 10 percent business, which is pretty accurate. At the museum, it was 90 percent business and 10 percent art. It was just constant, relentless fundraising. A certain kind of museum show simply wonâ€™t find a sponsor, but another kind is more appealing to the public and a bank will sign up. Iâ€™m used to working without compromise, and it was interesting going to a museum where thereâ€™s much more compromise.

â€œUnrealismâ€ is a collaboration between you and Larry Gagosianâ€”how did that take shape?

Iâ€™ve known Larry since 1979. I met him when he and Anina Nosei had a gallery in a loft on West Broadway across from the building with Castelli and Sonnabend, and they showed Salle who was a friend of mine. In the early â€˜80s, I used to go out to L.A. frequently to attend the openings of shows of friends of mine, like Basquiat and Kenny Scharf. I got to know him in a casual way, not just a business colleague way. We were both protÃ©gÃ©s of Leo Castelliâ€”we had that in common. And weâ€™ve worked with many of the same artists over the years: Basquiat, Jeff Koons, Cecily Brown.

People say, â€œIsnâ€™t he your competitor?â€ But I never thought that way. This is a very big platform. If some artist decides to leave me and go to Gagosian, itâ€™s not the end of the world. It opens up the opportunity to develop someone else. It goes both waysâ€”there are artists like Salle or Clemente who used to be with Gagosian and then they worked with me. There are never any recriminations or lawsuits. Iâ€™m relaxed about thisâ€”Iâ€™m very confident in what I can do. I never thought of this field as a zero-sum game.

You two do have very different business strategies, howeverâ€”he has a global franchise model, whereas you have focused on New York and just a couple of spaces.

For me, itâ€™s not business first. Iâ€™m much more about using the business structure to support my curatorial projects. Iâ€™ve found that the market system is a great system to support radical art and artistic innovation.

What do you make of the business challenges of running a smaller or mid-sized gallery today, especially in New York? There are the staggering expenses of participating in art fairs, on top of rising rents.

Just like the artists keep coming, the ground-level galleries keep coming. Artistic entrepreneurship is thriving here. Some of the most exciting places to encounter art in New York are the basement of Ramiken Crucible, the little storefront of JTT, and Real Fine Arts in Brooklyn underneath the highway. The artists who show at these places, and the people who want to buy their work, donâ€™t need a gigantic, slick, super-expensive gallery. Iâ€™m more stimulated by the experience of going into this alley behind the liquor store to get to Ramiken Crucible. The serious people love itâ€”thereâ€™s a sense of discovery and authenticity, and a number of artists also appreciate that.

Some artists are waiting for that invitation from the mega-gallery. Other galleries want to do something with them, and theyâ€™re holding back. And some of the mega-galleries do a really good job. But is Oscar Murilloâ€™s career going to be more interesting and dynamic and rewarding to him by being with David Zwirner than if he had stayed with Carlos/Ichikawa in London, where heâ€™s hanging out with other artists of his generation? Itâ€™s an interesting question. Iâ€™m always more enthusiastic about the model where the gallerist is about the same age as the artist, and they grow up together and establish something together.

One of the strategies that youâ€™ve been working with is to have less of a gallery presence and to focus on pop-up exhibitions.

Yes. Itâ€™s a much bigger reward for me to create a thematic exhibition, instead of just running as fast as I can on a treadmill to create 30 shows a year, which we used to do. We did â€œUnrealismâ€ pretty quickly, although itâ€™s a major effort. With â€œOverpop,â€ Iâ€™m taking more time. This is more what I want to do now, to do projects that take some time and have a book attached and that make a bigger impact. Also, rather than just representing artists I like, I can work with all galleries. With â€œUnrealism,â€ weâ€™re getting wonderful collaboration with everybody. Thatâ€™s something I was able to take advantage of at the museum, and I wanted it to continue. The show is a great collaboration, not just with Gagosian but with Zwirner, with Hauser & Wirth, with Jack Shainman, with many other galleries.

What do you think is the future of SoHo as an art neighborhood? There are very few galleries left in the area, and some of the ones that remain are consolidating or closing. Meanwhile, the Lower East Side is booming.

SoHo has a new dynamism, because of the Lower East Side. You can just walk right down Grand Streetâ€”itâ€™s a 10-minute walk. Itâ€™s a really central area for shopping, restaurants. Thereâ€™s Chanel here, but also thereâ€™s H&M, Uniqlo. Thereâ€™s something for everyone, no matter what your income level. Iâ€™m very populist, so I like that itâ€™s very central, very accessible. Every subway goes here.

The other new development, besides the Lower East Side galleries, is CondÃ© Nast and TIME and Fox going to the World Trade Center area. Itâ€™s one subway stop on the E train, and youâ€™re here. You can easily come here at lunch hour if youâ€™re working for Vogue.

So Iâ€™m very happyâ€”Iâ€™m not going anywhere. In August, Iâ€™m going to take back the Wooster Street space back. I had given a special five-year lease to the Swiss Instituteâ€”I was planning to be away, but I had always planned to take the space back.

So youâ€™ll operate it as a gallery again?

Yes, but again itâ€™s not like we represent this or that artistâ€”it would be thematic shows, orâ€¦ I have plenty of ideas. Not for month-to-month shows, but maybe shows that would be on for a couple of months. And then we would use this space [at 76 Grand Street] more as an office and showroom.

Is Brooklyn, where you had been looking for gallery space last year, off the table at this point?

Yes, Iâ€™m focusing here. I tried to make a deal to bring in a partner who I was connected with to buy a half-interest in a big property in Red Hook, and out of that I would get an exhibition space. It wasnâ€™t completed. Then I got this building back, and then I was invited to do this outdoor project in Coney Island. So I donâ€™t really need it now.

Can you tell me more about â€œOverpopâ€?

The theme of â€œUnrealismâ€ is very straightforwardâ€”the winds are shifting, and thereâ€™s some very fresh figurative painting, and weâ€™re seeing this cycle just like we did in 1980 or â€™82â€”a new interest in figuration. â€œOverpopâ€ is much more complicated. In a way, itâ€™s my sequel to â€œPost Human.â€

When I see something thatâ€™s out there that hasnâ€™t been fully articulated yet, that plenty of people are talking about, I want to rise to the challengeâ€”can I define what is important in this moment? Iâ€™m very interested in tendencies in art that coincide with trends in society and science. With this â€œOverpopâ€ moment, we see this convergence between artistic trends, social trends, technological trends. Thereâ€™s something really interesting there that can help us to understand and define our moment by looking at art.

For me the title is even more important than the essay. Itâ€™s crazy how few people actually read your essays, but everybody knows the title. With this group of artists, thereâ€™s a lot of debt to the foundation of Pop art, to Warhol and other artists in the Pop arena. Thereâ€™s also this confusion between art and popular culture. There are artists in â€œOverpopâ€ who work directly in popular cultureâ€”like Miranda July, or Harmony Korine. Spring Breakers is pop culture, but it has amazing artistic imagery and concepts.

Where exactly are you doing â€œOverpopâ€?

Itâ€™s going to open in Shanghai. Weâ€™re talking with an American museumâ€”I hope itâ€™s going to happen. Then itâ€™s going to the Sandretto Re Rebaudengo Foundation in Turinâ€”theyâ€™re very astute, they collect a lot of these artists. And weâ€™re doing a book, with [Karmaâ€™s] Brendan Dugan.

What else are you working on? I heard you were planning to do the â€œDiscoâ€ show you had wanted to do at MOCA.

Thatâ€™s all conceived and ready to go. But what I decided is that the â€œOverpopâ€ show is very timelyâ€”I have to do it now. The disco show, it doesnâ€™t matter whether itâ€™s done this year or three years from nowâ€”itâ€™s more historical, and people will love it then. So I put that off to do â€œOverpopâ€â€” I canâ€™t delay that show, because itâ€™s of this moment.

How would you characterize this current moment in the art world, aside from the issues in â€œOverpopâ€? What else is on your mind?

From my perspective, this whole gigantic structure of art fairs and auctions has become excessive. There will probably be some sort of correction, because itâ€™s just too extreme. But Iâ€™m also an idealist, and I love it that the art audience has become so much bigger. I do believe that art enhances peopleâ€™s lives, that art at its best can create more open and tolerant attitudes and understanding between people of diverse backgrounds. So I think itâ€™s good that the art world is much bigger.

I also donâ€™t want to be a curmudgeon and say, â€œItâ€™s ruined now,â€ or that the â€˜80s was the golden age. In the â€˜80s we had to listen to the people from the â€˜50s, who thought that Leo Castelli had ruined the art world! The big message is, contemporary art used to be quite marginal in the general culture and the economy, and now art is much more in the center.
